name: Kenny Q. Zhu
content: Kenny Q. Zhu's Home Page Kenny Q. Zhu (朱其立) Professor Dept. of Computer Science & Engineering University of Texas at Arlington Bio & Contact Publications (DBLP) (Google Scholar) Vita My Students (ACL Lab) Links Prospective graduate students: I am recruiting PhD and Masters students for the Spring/Fall 2026 admission. If you are curious, honest, independent and hardworking, and want to work on : Natural Language Processing, especially Animal Language Processing, please email your CV and transcripts to me! Prospective undergraduate students: Please check out our wonderful summer REU site research opportunity funded by National Science Foundation (NSF): Animal Language Processing and Understanding! News 10/3/2025: Our research is featured on UTA newspaper Shorthorn. 10/01/2025: Our canine vocalization research was featured on Dallas Morning News! 08/01/2025: Three of our papers on dog vocalization were accepted by ACM Multimedia 2025! Congrats to Hridayesh and Tuan! 07/31/2025: Our paper "Toward Automatic Discovery of a Canine Phonetic Alphabet" has won the ACL 2025 Outstanding Paper Award! It's one of the 26 papers that received this accolade. ACL 2025 published 3,400 papers. 05/15/2025: Two papers accepted by ACL 2025 main conference. Congrats to Theron and Minghao! 04/15/2025: ACL2 has just released a new canine vocalization understanding challenge as part of the IJCAI 2025 Competition Track. All are invited to participate! 02/25/2025: One full paper accepted by AAAI 2025, and three full papers accepted by NAACL 2025. 10/17/2024: Kenny Zhu was featured on an Atlantic magazine article about dog languages. 07/30/2024: Two papers accepted by EMNLP 2024 Findings. Congrats to Sinong, Xingyuan, Yvvonne and Haoan! 06/24/2024: Kenny Zhu appeared on CBS 11 Texas and ABC 8 (DFW) news to discuss his research on animal language processing and understanding. 05/12/2024: Kenny Zhu interviewed by UTA correspondent on the dog communications. 03/04/2024: One paper accepted by ICLR 2024. Congrats to Roy! Research My past work was focused on enabling machines to understand natural languages and further generate these languages, which is one of the most challenging tasks in artificial intelligence. My recent focus has been more interdisciplinary. At the heart of my research, I'm trying to answer the big science question: what's the relationship between intelligence and language? Specifically, i) is language (skill) a necessary part (or outcome) of intelligence? ii) can the use of a language or the lack of which affect the development of intelligence? To answer these questions, I have embarked on the following projects. Current Research Animal language processing and understanding (view demo) NLP for mental health Fusing structured knowledge with language models Good Research Advices How to write a good research paper. Simon Peyton Jones. Common errors in technical writing.. John Owens @ UC Davis and Kenny Zhu @ UTA. How to give a good research talk. Simon Peyton Jones.
